text_en: It makes me think about micro fitness again and like super tiny exercises and routines and how you think when you're doing something that's really super static, like any movement becomes important and you and I spend our lives sitting down. Because the practice of climbing the bell tower and ringing all the bells in a group became a passion that was somewhere between sport and play. And it basically consisted of pulling the bells, making the noise, but since there were so many, It was a group exercise in which it began to develop as a kind of game that consisted of seeing how many permutations they could get, how many different rhythms, like first one bell, then another, then another.

text_en: Well, they were the actresses, which we have called super fit actresses, because the seventeenth century in Spain was the heyday of the theater and unlike England, as I think we all know from the wonderful film Sex, Being and Love. In England women actresses were not allowed, so women's roles were played by these very young boys. But in Spain they could, in Spain there were women actresses who became very famous. But of course, on the one hand, the actresses had to submit themselves to a very meticulous control of their movements, that they were not too provocative, but still managed on the one hand to play the role they were assigned, which were sometimes risky roles, and on the other hand, they had to attract some attention from the public because they had to make money. But also, above all, women had to learn to master the risk involved in a very recent invention at the time, which was the stage machinery.

O sea, las prácticas físicas que eran más populares eran los birlos, lo que ahora llamamos bolos, el lanzamiento de barra, la lanza, que sería como lo que ahora entendemos por jabalina, los dardos y la espada, claro. Pero para hombres más delicados, como ciertos nobles y los que pertenecían a las jerarquías eclesiásticas, pues lo que se recomendaba pertenecer a la caza, el baile y los juegos de pelota. O sea, el fútbol, por ejemplo, que ahora entendemos por fútbol, era para gente delicadita. Pero nuestro Cristóbal, claro, él habla también del manejo de la espada, y efectivamente deja fuera a las mujeres. Porque él deja claro que este es un ejercicio que conviene a los mancebos. Y me hace mucha gracia que decía Cristóbal que cuando miraba a estos mancebos manejando la espada decía, no parecen los hombres sino demonios en aquella postura. O sea que imaginemos qué habría pensado él y qué habrían pensado los espectadores de la actriz Luisa Robles cuando estaba convertida sobre las tablas en una figura doblemente demoníaca.
text_en: What a genius, Luisa de Robles, and now we will see why. But, of course, there was a super clear, super strict categorization of which sports, which activities were suitable, not only for each gender, but also according to social class. That is, the physical practices that were most popular were the birlos, what we now call bowling, bar throwing, the spear, which would be like what we now understand by javelin, darts and the sword, of course. But for more delicate men, such as certain nobles and those who belonged to the ecclesiastical hierarchies, what was recommended was hunting, dancing and ball games. That is, soccer, for example, what we now understand as soccer, was for delicate people. But our Cristobal, of course, he also talks about the handling of the sword, and effectively leaves out women. Because he makes it clear that this is an exercise that suits young men. And I find it very funny that Cristobal said that when he looked at these young men handling the sword he said, they don't look like men but like demons in that posture. So let's imagine what he would have thought and what the spectators would have thought of the actress Luisa Robles when she was transformed on the stage into a doubly demonic figure.

speaker: B
text: Claro, y Cristóbal Méndez no lo pudo saber porque ya se había muerto, por suerte para él seguro, pero más demoníaca le hubiera parecido Luisa de Robles en un papel que tuvo que representar en una obra, además titulada El Anticristo, de Ruid y Alarcón. Porque en 1623 Ruid y Alarcón Un autor de comedias de la época va a representar esta obra, Titular del Anticristo, pero en el último minuto el actor que la había escogido, que se llamaba Manuel Vallejo, se arrepiente porque le dan mucho miedo las tramoyas. y Luisa de Robles, muy atrevidamente, se lanza a ofrecerse para representar el papel. Entonces, Luisa de Robles subió por la tramoya y saltó hacia la escotillón, es decir, que se jugó la vida para haberse matado. Fue un momento super sonado a principios del siglo XVII en Madrid y esta usurpación del momento de gloria de su compañero actor de reparto le aseguró a Luisa de Robles una fama que góngora que aprovecha para ridiculizar la falta de valentía y de virilidad del otro actor, de Manuel Vallejo, y mortaliza en uno de sus sonetos, es decir, como que Góngora le escribe un soneto a la valentía de Luisa de Robles. text_en: Of course, and Cristobal Mendez could not know because he had already died, luckily for him for sure, but more demonic would have seemed Luisa de Robles in a role he had to represent in a play, also entitled The Antichrist, of Ruid and Alarcon. Because in 1623 Ruid y Alarcón An author of comedies of the time is going to represent this play, Titular del Anticristo, but at the last minute the actor who had chosen it, who was called Manuel Vallejo, regrets because he is very afraid of the stage machinery. and Luisa de Robles, very boldly, throws herself to offer to play the role. Then, Luisa de Robles climbed up the stage and jumped towards the hatch, that is to say, she risked her life to have killed herself. It was a very famous moment at the beginning of the 17th century in Madrid and this usurpation of the moment of glory of her fellow actor assured Luisa de Robles a fame that Góngora took advantage of to ridicule the lack of courage and virility of the other actor, Manuel Vallejo, and mortalizes in one of his sonnets, that is, as if Góngora wrote a sonnet to the courage of Luisa de Robles.
